**The Reverberhusk**

’Twas klangorous, and the graffled walls
Did weep with weeping gloomth;
“Beware the Reverberhusk that squalls,
Its echo-fang and tooth!”

He took his Voidsound sword in hand,
His Thrum-plate on his chest,
To seek that grim and groaning land
And put it to the test.

He stood within the dripping hall
And heard its brattle-shriek,
A chitter-shape upon the wall,
Too terror-full to speak.

One, two! And through! The Voidsound blade

**The Murkling's Maw**

'Twas sun-scant, and the flumphing mist
Did slumper on the wold;
The grickle-grass all grimly hissed,
And all the air grew cold.

"Beware the Murkling, son, my own,
Its eyes of bog-fire bright!
Beware its slorping, glurking groan,
And jaws that chump and bite!"

He took his gleamsnicker blade so keen,
And long the foe he sought;
He strode into that soupy scene,
Bemused in grummish thought.

And as in uffish stance he stood,
The Murkling, with its eyes aflame,
Came whiffling through the writhing wood,
And burblingly it came!

One, two! One, two! And through and through
The gleamsnicker blade went snicker-snack!
It left the beast of ghastly hue,
And with its head he gallumphed back.

"And hast thou slain the Murkling dread?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
Oh frabjous day! Callooh! Callay!"
He chortled in his joy.

'Twas sun-scant, and the flumphing mist

The grickle-grass no longer hissed,

**The Déjàvour**

’Ware well the Déjàvour, my son!
The path you've trod before,
Its twice-felt shadows have begun
To creep beneath your door.

He took his Mind-Blade, sharp and true,
And steeled his frembled soul,
He sought the false world, old-and-new,
To make his memory whole.

It came fore-whiffling through the mist,
A shimmer-fangéd dread,
With echo-claws it swung and missed,
*Clack-clack* beside his head.

“You’ve slain the beast of What-Has-Been?
Come to my arms, my boy!
Oh day of nows! Oh joy-glee-keen!”
He chortled out his joy.

Beware the Déjàvour, my friend,
The path you re-perceive;
Its twice-felt shadows make an end
And grant your mind reprieve.

The Scramble-Track

“Forewarn the Scramble-Track, my childe!
The jaws that crunch, the claws that clinch!
Forewarn the footpaths weird and wild,
And shun the grimping Grumbletrod’s hard pinch!”

He took his whickersnack in hand,
And long the trodsome foe he sought.
He snoofed along the tampered land,
And stood in uffish thought.

And as in uffish thought he stood,
The Grumbletrod, with eyes of glame,
Came brumbling from the tangly wood,
And grumbled as it came!

One, two! and thwack! So sharp and fast
The whickersnack went clitter-clack!
Its grumbles were its very last,
He flung it on his back.

“And hast thou smitched the Grumbletrod?
Come to my arms, my gleamish boy!
Oh trillant day! By root and clod!”
He guffled in his joy.

Now traipse upon the Scramble-Track,
No jaws will crunch, no claws will clinch.
The folk may wend their own way back,
And feel no Grumbletrod’s hard pinch.

### The Smoodge

’Twas coff-o’clock, the glumphing gears
Did whirrle in the platen-works;
“Beware the Smoodge, my son, with fears,”
The elder cubicle-clerk quirks.
“Its inker-jaws, its fangle-claws!”
He warned beside the printle-box,
“The page-flims scrunchled in its maws,
The grindle-shriek which stops the clocks!”

He took his dexter-hand in hold,
Long time the crumply foe he sought—
So, steeled his nerve against the scold,
He stood in uffish, worried thought.
The printle-box began to groan,
A whicker-snarl, a gruncheon deep;
The page-flims crumpled and were thrown
Within the tray-gate’s narrow sleep.

His fingers, nimble and so fast,
Unclatched the hatch with clicky-snap!
He saw the grelching beast, at last,
And pulled it from the clenchy trap.
He yanked it forth, a tattered prize,
All toner-smirched and ripped in two;
He slew the Smoodge before its rise
Could stop the morning’s memo through.

“And have you slain the horrid Smoodge?
Come to my arms, my beamish boy!
Oh, frellish day! Huzzah! Un-fudge!”
He chortled in his office-joy.
“You’ve pulled the page, you’ve won the fray,
Now let the printle-box resume!”
He clapped his back, “Hoorah! Salay!”
And banished all the toner-gloom.

’Twas coff-o’clock, the grateful gears
Did chuckle-clack and softly hum;
The elder clerk had calmed his fears,
The gruncheon-shrieks were rendered dumb.
